newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: PRESS DIGEST - New Zealand newspapers - June 4.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - New Zealand newspapers - June 4.

text.p: Second storm strikes: Coast battens down hatches: Mahia Peninsula residents battened down for their second night without power on Tuesday night as a storm lashed Hawke's Bay. Page 1.

Labour would keep top finance job says Cullen: Labour would insist on the top finance job in any future coalition government with the Alliance, Labour deputy leader and finance spokesman Michael Cullen said on Tuesday. Page 2.

Anglers want equality for fishing licences: The government should stop dithering and join a legal challenge to the rights of some Maoris to catch trout without a licence, the Freswater Anglers Federation said on Tuesday. Page 2.

PDL just manages target profit: Christchurch-based electrical and plastics manufacturer PDL Holdings has only just achieved its forecast profit, with a result of $12.53 million for the year to March 1997. Page 16.

Consumers forecast to lead economic growth: New Zealand's economy will grow slower than the rest of the Asia Pacific region in the next two years, but will benefit from a consumer-led recovery, according to a report carried out for the Pacific Economic Cooperation council. Page 16.

Big demand for Restaurant Brands shares: The float of 85 million Restaurant shares is understood to have been heavily oversubscribed by the time bidding by retail investors closed on Tuesday afternoon. Page 16.
Man shot dead in hold-up: A 22-year-old man was shot dead on Tuesday night during an armed hold-up at the Caledonian Hotel in St Albans, Christchurch. Page 1.
Stirling Sports stake to Asia: The owners of New Zealand sports retail chain, Stirling Sports, have sold a 35 percent stake to three Singaporean brothers. Page 21.
Telecom contracts out phone line maintenance: Telecom has contracted an outside company to maintain 30 percent of its Christchurch telephone network. Page 25.
Economists predict a loosening of reins: A further but modest loosening of the monetary reins is in prospect after the Reserve Bank's monetary policy statement on June 27.

Delegation comes with spicy message for NZ: A six-member delegation of Indian spice exporters arrived in Auckland on Tuesday to talk to local inporters keen to take advantage of a growing local interest in Indian cruisine.
